While supporting, documenting, maintaining and testing Rhino support isn't such a big deal, I would promote for dropping it. Everything that makes us leaner makes us faster.
Why dropping Rhino?
* The latest release of Rhino is 1.7R4 from June, 2012 [1] which targets JavaScript 1.7 [2]. * The latest qooxdoo mailing list question for Rhino is from June 2012 [3]. * While pull requests are accepted there seems no real ongoing activity on their GitHub page (only 5 commits in 2013, and no commits in 2014) [4]. * With the rise of Node.js I see no real justification for using Rhino nowadays other than that you're stuck with using Java.
[1] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/New_in_Rhino_1.7R4 [2] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/New_in_JavaScript/1.7 [3] http://qooxdoo.678.n2.nabble.com/Environment-for-runtime-name-is-wrong-on-Rhino-td7580436.html [4] https://github.com/mozilla/rhino/commits/master
I think a small note somewhere in the manual in the vain of "... should also work with Rhino, but not officially supported by us ..." is sufficient.
